tab.name: intro
tab.label: Summary
tab.content: Bath is one of the finest small cities in Britain. Catch the warm light of a fine morning on the elegant golden limestone facades of the Georgian town houses and you'll see why. Despite the historical grandeur it is a buzzing and busy place with loads of great cafes, museums and highly individual shops. Bath is wonderfully preserved, with plenty of fascinating hidden corners, making it the perfect place for a Treasure Hunt!

tab.name: details
tab.label: Hunt Info
tab.content:
Hunts The pack includes an easy and hard version of the main treasure trail and a bonus puzzle.

Duration 2 or 3 hours, not including breaks.

Suitability Suitable for any size of group from 1 to 8, good for families. The streets of Bath are accessible to all, though there are some hilly roads and a detour may be necessary to avoid steps.

Requirements Just a pencil and paper, and a sensible pair of shoes.

tab.name: todo
tab.label: Things to do
tab.content:
• Visit the Roman Baths, perhaps the best preserved Roman remains in Britain
  • Have a relaxing afternoon being pampered at Thermae Bath Spa
  • Explore the countryside and find the beautiful little Iford Manor
  • Visit in December to enjoy the Bath Christmas Market

tab.name: intro
tab.label: Summary
tab.content: Brighton is a lively and eclectic city on the south coast, the first place in Britain to elect a Green MP to parliament. Here in the eccentric lanes you can find antiques and sticks of rock rubbing up against alternative lifestyles and bohemian boutiques. There are dozens of intriguing little corners to explore, and endless distractions for the curious. The ideal location for a Treasure Hunt!

tab.name: details
tab.label: Hunt Info
tab.content:
Hunts The pack includes a treasure trail and a bonus round.

Duration 2 hours or so, not including breaks.

Suitability Suitable for any size of group from 1 to 8, good for families. The streets of Brighton are accessible to all, though there are some hilly roads.

Requirements Just a pencil and paper, and a sensible pair of shoes.

tab.name: todo
tab.label: Things to do
tab.content:
• Visit the Brighton Pavilion, a Prince's playhouse
  • Come in May to enjoy England's largest performing arts festival, The Brighton Festival
  • Amble around the North Laines, the biggest gathering of eclectic one-off shopping outside London
  • In May or December, shop for arts and crafts at the Artists' Open Houses

tab.name: intro
tab.label: Summary
tab.content: The city of Bristol has a long and colourful history, closely associated with the sea. This is still very much in evidence in the docks and quays that reach right into the centre of the city. Away from the main shopping area there are many beautiful buildings and fascinating clues to Bristol's grand past. The perfect area to explore on a Treasure Hunt!

tab.name: details
tab.label: Hunt Info
tab.content:
Hunts The pack includes a treasure trail and a bonus round.

Duration 2 hours or so, not including breaks.

Suitability Suitable for any size of group from 1 to 8, good for families. The streets of Bristol are accessible to all, though there are some hilly roads. There are one set of steps in the hunt which can be detoured.

Requirements Just a pencil and paper, and a sensible pair of shoes.

tab.name: todo
tab.label: Things to do
tab.content:
• Enjoy the huge permenant street art on Nelson Street, created by the See No Evil project.
  • Stop for a snack at the lively St Nicholas Market and explore the jumble of shops.
  • Step aboard the SS Great Britain and explore Brunel's great ship.

tab.name: intro
tab.label: Summary
tab.content: Bruton is a small country town in a beautiful part of Somerset, full of interest for the explorer. The surrounding area is scattered with picturesque villages down winding lanes. This part of Somerset is well off the beaten track, but easily accessible if you're staying in Bristol, Bath or Salisbury. The perfect area to explore with a Treasure Hunt!

tab.name: details
tab.label: Hunt Info
tab.content:
Hunts The pack includes a treasure trail by car around part of Somerset.

Duration 3-4 hours, including 38 miles of driving.

Suitability Suitable for any size of group from 1 to 8, good for families. The roads are mainly country lanes, with only short stretches on minor A roads. There is some walking at each stop, but mainly on pavement.

Requirements A car, an OS map, a pencil and paper, as well as a sensible pair of shoes.

MapThe OS map for this trail is the Landranger Map 183, Yeovil & Frome

tab.name: todo
tab.label: Things to do
tab.content:
• If you have time, visit Sherborne, a Dorset town a few miles south of this hunt and a real gem
  • The gardens at Stourhead are a stunning find when the weather is fine
  • You are not very far from the famous Longleat Safari Park here either
  • The city of Wells is a little further, but it is a magical town to explore

tab.name: intro
tab.label: Summary
tab.content: Everyone knows the shiny towers of banks and big business that mark the skyline of the City of London, but do you know about the winding medieval alleyways, unexpected old churches and odd memorials that can still be found in the shadow of these buildings? The ancient history of the city is still there to be found, and what better way than on a Treasure Hunt!

tab.name: details
tab.label: Hunt Info
tab.content:
Hunts The pack includes a treasure trail and a bonus round.

Duration 2 hours or so, not including breaks.

Suitability Suitable for any size of group from 1 to 8, good for families. The streets of the city are accessible to all, and any steps can be detoured around. There are two parks to enter but they should be freely accessible in daylight hours.

Requirements Just a pencil and paper, and a sensible pair of shoes.

tab.name: todo
tab.label: Things to do
tab.content:
• It's not cheap, but if you've never been to the Tower of London you really should go once – it's right at the heart of our history
  • For a bird's eye view of the city with unusual food from a snack to a feast, try Duck & Waffle atop Heron Tower, open 24/7
  • Beyond Liverpool St Station is Spitalfields Market. You could spend a day shopping for gifts here, all under cover

tab.name: intro
tab.label: Summary
tab.content: Ludlow is a quintessential and beautiful English market town in Shropshire. Indeed John Betjeman once wrote “Ludlow is the loveliest town in England” and more recently Jeremy Paxman said “Has there ever been a visitor to Ludlow who hasn't wished they lived there?” Needless to say it is a wonderful place in which to set a Treasure Hunt. With numerous independent shops and restaurants it feels like a place with a strong and vibrant community that hasn't changed much in many years.

tab.name: details
tab.label: Hunt Info
tab.content:
Hunts The pack includes an easy and a hard treasure trail, a set of extra explorer puzzles and a bonus round.

Duration 2 hours to a full day, not including breaks.

Suitability Suitable for any size of group from 1 to 8, good for families. The streets of Ludlow are accessible to all, any steps can be detoured around. The hard trail includes an unmade country path that may be muddy after rain.

Requirements Just a pencil and paper, and a sensible pair of shoes.

tab.name: todo
tab.label: Things to do
tab.content:
• The big date in Ludlow's calendar is the annual Food Festival, one of the first and definitely the best in the whole country
  • Right in the middle of the town, Ludlow Castle is a grand ruin of a medieval fortress, great for exploring
  • If you are looking for a lunch stop, the Green Cafe is best – so good, in fact, that you'd be wise to book
  • A few miles north of Ludlow the fortified manor of Stokesay Castle is a gem, the finest building of its kind in the country

tab.name: intro
tab.label: Summary
tab.content: The Oxford University is the oldest university in the English-speaking world. It comprises 38 colleges, the oldest of which are University College, Balliol and Merton. The most recent was Green Templeton College, founded in 2008. Women were first allowed into the University in 1878, but now all colleges are co-educational.

tab.name: details
tab.label: Hunt Info
tab.content:
Hunts The pack includes a treasure trail around Oxford.

Duration 2 hours or so, not including breaks.

Suitability Suitable for any size of group from 1 to 8, good for families. The streets of Oxford are accessible to all, and any steps can be detoured around. All the areas entered on this trail should be freely accessible in daylight hours.

Requirements Just a pencil and paper, and a sensible pair of shoes.

tab.name: todo
tab.label: Things to do
tab.content:
• Oxford is all about learning, so take time to explore the world-renowned Ashmolean Museum
  • The Pitt Rivers Museum looks and feels like a proper old museum, and is absolutely packed with artefacts from every corner of the globe
  • Not far from Oxford is the picturesque town of Woodstock and the enormously impressive Blenheim Palace, both well worth visiting

tab.name: intro
tab.label: Summary
tab.content: Richmond is a splendid town on the banks of the River Thames to the west of London. Once home to kings and queens as the site of Richmond Palace, this is still a prosperous area. With a handsome high street, a beautiful riverside, plenty of green spaces and stunning views from Richmond Hill it's easy to see why. So why not let us show you the best little corners of Richmond-upon-Thames with a Treasure Hunt?

tab.name: details
tab.label: Hunt Info
tab.content:
Hunts The pack includes a treasure trail and a bonus round.

Duration 2 hours or so, not including breaks.

Suitability Suitable for any size of group from 1 to 8, good for families. The streets of Richmond are accessible to all, and any steps can be detoured around.

Requirements Just a pencil and paper, and a sensible pair of shoes.

tab.name: todo
tab.label: Things to do
tab.content:
• It's only a ten minute walk from Richmond train station to Kew Gardens, an amazing place to visit at any time of year whether you are a keen gardener or not
  • Richmond Park is unique, there's nowhere else in London where you can walk for hours and fool yourself into thinking you're in rolling countryside miles from anywhere
  • The Petersham Nurseries is what anyone would think of if them picture an idyllic English garden nursery. It has a lovely cafe and restaurant too, though you must book for lunch

tab.name: intro
tab.label: Summary
tab.content: Throughout history the south bank of the Thames in London has been a less affluent area, a melting pot of people and a lively neighbourhood. This is still true today! But it is also true that the roads and passages of Southwark hold many clues to the riches of the past. Surely a great place to explore with a Treasure Hunt?

tab.name: details
tab.label: Hunt Info
tab.content:
Hunts The pack includes a treasure trail and a bonus round.

Duration 2 hours or so, not including breaks.

Suitability Suitable for any size of group from 1 to 8, good for families. The streets of Southwark are accessible to all, and any steps can be detoured around. All the areas explored should be freely accessible in daylight hours.

Requirements Just a pencil and paper, and a sensible pair of shoes.

tab.name: todo
tab.label: Things to do
tab.content:
• Your treasure hunt takes you right through Borough Market, and if it's open there's nowhere better to find snacks or lunch around here
  • At Shakespeare's Globe they perform traditional renditions of the bard's great plays in evocative surroundings
  • The Tate Modern holds a really important collection of modern art in a very unique building
  • Have a look at the Old Operating Theatre Museum for a unique insight into how medicine used to be done

tab.name: intro
tab.label: Summary
tab.content: Stratford-upon-Avon is the city of the bard, renowned as Shakespeare's birthplace. Perhaps because of this it has kept much of the charm and character of a country market town while playing host to so many thousands of tourists annually. Of course, if you want to find some of the hidden corners and interesting details of Stratford that the tourist crowds seldom see you would be wise to try this Treasure Hunt.

tab.name: details
tab.label: Hunt Info
tab.content:
Hunts The pack includes an easy and hard version of the main treasure trail, a set of extra explorer puzzles and a bonus round.

Duration 2 hours to a full day, not including breaks.

Suitability Suitable for any size of group from 1 to 8, good for families. The streets of Stratford are accessible to all, and any areas included in the trails should be freely accessible in daylight hours.

Requirements Just a pencil and paper, and a sensible pair of shoes.

tab.name: todo
tab.label: Things to do
tab.content:
• You shouldn't visit Stratford without seeing some top-quality Shakespeare at the RSC's theatres
  • Not so very far from Stratford is one of the greatest medieval ruins in Britain, Warwick Castle - beware, though very impressive it is also very expensive

tab.name: intro
tab.label: Summary
tab.content: Windsor town is dominated by the majestic Windsor Castle, one of the great royal residences of Britain. It is also a charming town to visit, with a cluster of interesting shops and enticing cafes and plenty of easily overlooked details hinting at the royal connection. What's more, a short walk over the River Thames is the town of Eton, home to one of the most famous old schools in the world. This Treasure Hunt draws both of these towns together in a fascinating walk through history.

tab.name: details
tab.label: Hunt Info
tab.content:
Hunts The pack includes a treasure trail and a bonus round.

Duration 2 hours or so, not including breaks.

Suitability Suitable for any size of group from 1 to 8, good for families. The streets of Windsor are accessible to all, and any steps can be detoured around. All the areas explored should be freely accessible in daylight hours.

Requirements Just a pencil and paper, and a sensible pair of shoes.

tab.name: todo
tab.label: Things to do
tab.content:
• The Royal Landscape around Windsor includes some fantastic places to walk and gardens to explore – Virginia Water is our favourite
  • The Thames Path around Windsor and Eton is good for a ramble or a bicycle ride, you can see Eton Dorney where the Olympic rowing took place
  • If your wallet is weighing you down, why not splash out on dinner at The Fat Duck in nearby Bray? One of the world's best restaurants
